Dear Mr. McKeage:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Barbara A Cote, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation In July 2022, youth was able to cheek their medication and take
them all at once. If policy was followed by staff, this would not
have been able to happen.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant is DHHS Worker investigating a previous
complaint. Complainant had no further information to report.
Youth A was interviewed via Teams on March 14, 2023, in
collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth A reported he brought
back six “perks” (Percocet) from a home visit in July 2022. Youth
A stated he refused to allow staff to do a search of his belongings
when he returned to the facility. Youth A reported he was
collecting the pills two to three days prior to when he took all the
pills. Youth A stated he cheeked Adderall, Vyvanse and Seroquel.
Youth A reported staff had him open his mouth, lift his tongue, and
use his finger to go around his gums to show the medication was
not in his mouth. Youth A described cheeking as he would keep
the medication in the back of his throat and cough it back up after
staff would have him open his mouth and complete the medication
check. Youth A stated every staff member that administered
medication checked to make sure the medication was not in his
mouth. Youth A reported he could not recall who the staff
member was that administered the medication when he cheeked
the medication. Youth A stated every staff member did the same
procedure when administering medication. Youth A denied any
staff not checking his mouth after administering medication.
Youth A stated he was caught cheeking his medication, so his
medication was crushed.
2

Youth A described staff watching him closely because he was
self-harming by cutting his arm. Youth A stated staff, he could not
recall who, were watching him through the bedroom window and
watched him take a handful of medication. Youth A stated staff
took him to the hospital and when he returned to the facility, he
was on a safety plan with one-to-one staffing. Youth A stated the
staff at Bay Pines did what they could to help him, and he was at
the “max benefit.” Youth A reported staff did not do anything
wrong.
Therapist was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
15, 2023. DHHS Worker joined the interview by TEAMS.
Therapist stated she sat with Youth A at the hospital the night
Youth A said he took the pills. Therapist stated she never
believed Youth A took the pills because his behavior never
changed at the hospital. Therapist described Youth A sitting
calmly at the hospital, watching TV, making jokes, visiting with
her, and talking with hospital staff. Therapist reported Youth A did
not seem effected, he was very awake and alert. Therapist stated
Youth A told her he was not trying to kill himself; he was just trying
to get high and forget. Therapist could not recall if Pathway came
to the hospital to evaluate Youth A.
Therapist described the steps as to how staff pass medication to
youth as: Staff have the youth come out of their room, staff give
youth one medication at a time, staff have the youth drink water
from a cup, the youth stick out their tongue, staff visually check
the youth’s mouth, and then the staff initial the youths’ Medication
Administration Record (MAR) sheet for each medication given.
Therapist stated if a youth refuses their medication staff mark a
“R” on the MAR sheet. Therapist stated there will never be a
blank square on the MAR unless the medication is a PRN, an as
needed medication. Therapist described if a youth is on a home
pass or leave of absence from the facility staff write “H” or “LOA”
on the MAR sheet for those specific dates for each medication.
Therapist stated if a youth is caught cheeking their medication
each medication that can be crushed, will be and that is how the
youth will take the medication.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
15, 2023. DHHS Worker joined the interview by TEAMS. Staff
1 could not recall Youth A cheeking his medication and taking
them all at once. Staff 1 reported always doing thorough checks
of Youth A’s mouth when passing medication. Staff 1 denied ever
catching Youth A cheeking his medication. Staff 1 stated if a
youth is caught cheeking medication, then the medication gets
3

crushed. Staff 1 described the medication pass process as:
Medications are passed to youth one at a time, medication is
placed in a cup, youth takes medication, youth is given a cup of
water to swallow, staff checks the cup to make sure it is empty,
youth sticks out their tongue, lifts their tongue up and youth swaps
their mouth with their finger all while staff visually check the
youth’s mouth to ensure the medication has been swallowed.
Staff 1 stated staff then initial the box on the MAR for the specific
medication that was passed to the youth.
Staff 1 reported there should never be any blanks on a MAR
sheet. Staff 1 stated staff initials or a “R” if a youth refuses their
medication would be in each medication box on the MAR. Staff 1
reported if a youth’s medication is ordered to be crushed the MAR
sheet will indicate “crush” medication. Staff 1 stated there is a tool
staff use to crush the medication.
Nurse was interviewed face to face at the facility on March 15,
2023. DHHS Worker joined the interview by TEAMS. Nurse
was interviewed again via Teams on March 16, 2023, in
collaboration with DHHS Worker. Nurse reviewed and
explained the documents from Youth A’s hospital visit on July 30,
2022. Nurse reported the comprehensive metabolic panel did not
show any values out of the ordinary and there were no
imbalanced electrolytes. Nurse stated if Youth A did take the
medication Youth A said he took, the medication would absolutely
show up within thirty minutes of the body processing the
medications. Nurse reported the medication Youth A said he took
would show up under the amphetamine/methamphetamine and
opiates section of the comprehensive metabolic panel, which all
documented non detected. Nurse stated the hospital report shows
Youth A’s blood values were all normal and nothing concerning.
Nurse reported if Youth A took the medication he said, Youth A’s
vitals would be different and Youth A’s physical symptoms and
demeaner from a drug overdose would be documented by hospital
staff.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on March
15, 2023. DHHS Worker joined the interview by TEAMS. Staff
2 stated he heard Youth A was cheeking his medication, but Staff
2 does not really know if Youth A was or not. Staff 2 stated he
always checked Youth A’s mouth and he never caught Youth A
cheeking medication. Staff 2 described the medication passing
process as: Staff give youth one medication at a time, youth
swallows medication, youth drink a cup of water, youth lift their
tongue, youth sweeps their finger around their mouth and coughs
4

into their elbow. Staff 2 reported staff watch youth do these steps
to ensure the medication is not being cheeked and then staff initial
the MAR next to each medication given. Staff 2 reported if a
youth refuses their medication a “R” is written in the box on the
MAR. Staff 2 stated there should never be a blank box on the
MAR sheet but sometimes staff forget to write their initials.
Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D were separately interviewed
face to face at the facility on March 15, 2023. Each youth
reported every time they take medication staff check to ensure the
medication was swallowed. Each of the youth described how staff
pass medication as the same; medication given one at a time,
youth drink a cup of water, youth stick out their tongue and swipe
their mouth with their finger. Each youth stated if caught cheeking
medication, staff crush the medication. All the youth denied any
staff member not checking to make sure medication is swallowed.
Staff 3 was interviewed via Teams March 16, 2023, in
collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 3 reported through the
window of Youth A’s door she saw him holding something in his
hand then put his hand to his mouth. Staff 3 stated Youth A told
her what and how many pills were in his hand and that is the
information she put in the incident report. Staff 3 reported she
took what Youth A said seriously even though she could not
confirm Youth A had pills in his hand. Staff 3 stated she later
learned nothing was found in Youth A’s system.
Staff 3 described the medication passing process as: Staff give
youth one medication at a time, youth swallows medication, youth
drink a cup of water, youth sweep their finger around their mouth,
cough into their elbow, then lift their tongue. Staff 3 reported staff
watch youth do these steps to ensure the medication is not being
cheeked.
DHHS Worker did not have any findings in the investigation.
Documents Reviewed:
• Incident Report dated 07/30/22 for Youth A describes
Youth A taking “approximately five Vyvanse pills and five
Seroquel pills.” Youth A’s interview on 03/14/23 of what
pills he took is different than what Youth A told Staff 3 he
took on 07/30/22.
• Medical Encounter Note for Youth A from the hospital dated
07/30/22: Note states, “Youth A reported he took a weeks’
worth of medication all at once.” Physical exam listed all
categories as “normal” and Youth A being “alert, and
5

oriented to person, place, and time.” Comprehensive
Metabolic Panel showed all categories in normal range and
the comprehensive drug screen listed, “non detected.”
• Bay Pines Medication Administration Policy 381: consistent
with how Therapist, Staff 1, Staff 2, and each youth
described passing medication. Policy was also consistent
with how Therapist, Staff 1 and Staff 2 described how to
initial the MAR.
• July and August 2022 MAR sheets for Youth A: Numerous
blank squares for five different medications for multiple
different dates.
• Training Records for Staff 1 and Staff 2: Medication
Administration training was completed for both staff on
07/26/22 and 01/09/23.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as the medical encounter note
from the hospital for Youth A showed no drugs detected in Youth
A’s system. Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D each
reported all staff check to ensure medication is swallowed.
Therapist, Staff 1, and Staff 2 described how medication is passed
to youth which was the same as the facility’s policy.
The facility is found in non-compliance for Youth A’s July and
August 2022 MAR sheet not being properly completed by staff.
Multiple boxes for five prescribed medications on the MAR sheets
were blank. Staff’s initials should be in the box if the medication
was dispensed to Youth A or a “R” if Youth A refused the
mediation that day. Therapist, Staff 1, and Staff 2 reported there
should never be an empty box on a youth’s MAR sheet.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
